anchors.  Aesthetically, this climb looks great; but the actual climbing is not as exciting as it appears.  The crux is about 20 feet up.  If you stay in the crack and not wander to the ledges on your left, you will get the most out of the climb.
protection: Small stoppers, up to 1" cams, and two double slings for the anchor to avoid rope damage on the lip.  This climb offers excellent protection.  Use the
Brain Cloud
bolted anchors.

description: Climb the chimney/slot/gully immediately left of "
Feeding Frenzy
".  This has no fixed anchors, but there is an easy walk-off around either side of the MBA Buttress.  It is an obvious but forgettable line.
protection: Standard gear rack.

description: This is an interesting line that climbs much easier than it would appear and requires far less chimneying that you might think.  It has a bolted anchor, so it has been climbed before, but it remains somewhat loose and dirty in spots.
This obvious, flared chimney is to the right of
Rusty, Small Hole Hanger Route

.  Start up on face holds, which seem to incline you to face right.  It may be a bit challenging to get gear in this section as the crack is shallow and irregular to some.  When two large footholds appear on the left, you can switch to more right side in.  Face holds keep appearing and allow you to avoid much friction on your back.  Once above the chimney taper, the footholds on the right get slopey.  Yard up onto the ledge and the two bolt anchor.
If you have a name or FA, let me know and I'll update the info.
location: This obvious, flared chimney is to the right of
Rusty, Small Hole Hanger Route
protection: Standard rack.

4.fa: led on gear by at least 1999, bolted by Dan Hare & Tom Kohlmann,  2008
description: Climb the right-facing corner that has a nice, thin, finger crack at its back to a ledge below the upper face.  Clip two bolts, or don't, on the face and climb into the perfect hand crack at the top.
location: It lies 20' right of
Intuition
or 20' left of
The Ground Doesn't Lie
protection: Medium nuts for the first part, then I plugged a #0.5 C4 and a #1 C4 at the top past the two bolts.

description: This wide crack is right of
This Ain't Naturita Pilgrim
and left of
The Fabulous Flying Carrs Route

.  There is a little of everything: offwidth, stems, and chimney.  If you're not William Howard Taft, you can tunnel through the chockstone at the top and belay from above.  Otherwise, go out and around the chockstone (recommended); and you can traverse right to the chain anchors on
The Fabulous Flying Carrs Route
.  There are a few loose pebbles, and the route is shady on a hot afternoon.
protection: Bring pro to 3" and slings.

description: About 40' left of
The Ground Doesn't Lie
, climb a dirty/broken chimney/dihedral to a ledge, then go up the face following the three bolts present.  There is a two bolt anchor on the face where it finally gets interesting.
location: This is in the Overhang area, left of
The Ground Doesn't Lie
protection: Three bolts, but a large nut protects the run out before the first bolt, which is about 20' off the deck.

description: The first part of this route climbs up now clean and bulgy cracks past good gear to the obvious ledge. Once on the ledge the route proceeds up the north-facing slab via fun moves past past 2 bolts to a fun mantel move onto another bivy ledge. Once on the ledge, climb past a bolt and then left to a chain anchor.
location: This route starts just right of "
2 Ways 2 Hell
" or 15 feet [left] of "
Smear Me A Beer
protection: 3 bolts and gear to a #1 Camalot.

description: This is another squeezed in trad line between a couple bolted lines,
Pack 'o Bobs
and
Wholly Holey
.  I'm confident it's been climbed, but it is not listed in the Haas guidebook.
Start as for either
Pack 'o Bobs
or
Wholly Holey
.  If you like, you can clip the 1st bolt of
Wholly Holey
, I did.  Then go up the crack on gear.  The crux is probably at the top of the crack.  Then, it continues up into chimney terrain.  At the top of the chimney, you can make a reverse, mini-
Fine Jade, P6
-like move around to the anchors of
Wholly Holey
Per
Sean Riley
BEWARE!
The "chimney" is actually a giant, detached block the size of a refrigerator.
Do NOT chimney on it
. This block now wobbles and will fall if pushed.
location: This lies between
Pack 'o Bobs
and
Wholly Holey
protection: +/- 1 bolt, cams from orange Alien/#0.5 Camalot to #3 Camalot (doubles of #1), #4 BD wire, #12 BD wire, a few shoulder length slings.

properties.4: {'route_name': 'Another Unnamed Billy Bob Route', 'grade': {'YDS': '5.7+', 'French': '5a', 'Ewbanks': '15', 'UIAA': 'V+', 'ZA': '13', 'British': 'MVS 4b'}, 'safety': '', 'type': {'sport': True}, 'fa': 'unknown', 'description': ['This route is called "Sloping Forehead" in Stewart Green\'s "Rock Climbing Colorado."', '', 'It begins just right of the top of the approach trail; two lines right of "', "This Ain't Naturita, Pilgrim", '", and one line right of "', "The Fabulous Flying Carr's Route", '".', '', 'Start on the left side of an arete, traverse right after the third bolt, and top out at an anchor shared with "', "Pack 'o Bobs", '".', '', 'A good beginner lead and an easy warm up.'], 'location': '', 'protection': ['4 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.'], 'metadata': {'left_right_seq': '35', 'parent_lnglat': [-105.21695, 39.76834], 'parent_sector': 'Overhang Area', 'mp_route_id': '105761445', 'mp_sector_id': '105744732'}}

description: Get off the ground and you're in the clear. The highlight is the low angle, lightning bolt crack up high. It is spooky and loose. Just don't pull outward.
location: This is just left of
Sharkcicle
protection: Standard rack.

description: This is an angling crack with a [former] bird's nest just right of a rocky buttress which is right of
Hand Crack
. Do an easy boulder start to an angling crack, and belay on gear.
If desired, a TR can be set up by walking up the cliff 150 yards to the (north) left of the route.
location: This is right of
Handcrack
and left of
Al & Mike's Frosty Little Adventure
protection: Nuts and a single set of cams up to #4. There are no anchors, so belay on gear.

description: This has decent moves.
location: It is left of "
Jim's Myrtle Spurge
protection: No anchors (
eds. old buttonheads without hangers, which can be backed up
), it is pretty difficult to set up and direct your rope where it should be. This is not the easiest to TR!

description: Follow the left-leaning crack.
location: This is just to the left of
Scraping the Barrel
protection: Standard rack, walk off.
Eds. now there are two anchor bolts from which you can rappel.  Thanks, Jay!

description: Ascend the left edge of a pillar to a shared anchor with "
My Big Red Catcher's Mitt
protection: 3 bolts, 2 anchor rings.

properties.4: {'route_name': "Jim's Myrtle Spurge", 'grade': {'YDS': '5.7', 'French': '5a', 'Ewbanks': '15', 'UIAA': 'V+', 'ZA': '13', 'British': 'MVS 4b'}, 'safety': '', 'type': {'tr': True}, 'fa': 'Tim Klein and Locker', 'description': ['Start as if doing "', "Mark Hamill's", '" (sound\'s a little kinky!), move immediately left.'], 'location': ['This is just to the left of "', "Mark Hamill's Face", '" and is toproped off of separate anchors.'], 'protection': ['2 Fixe anchors with[out] screw links.'], 'metadata': {'left_right_seq': '2', 'parent_lnglat': [-105.22476, 39.77386], 'parent_sector': 'Risk Area, The', 'mp_route_id': '108133927', 'mp_sector_id': '105744764'}}

description: This line follows the nice crack to the left of
Kevin Spies the Line
. I would not consider it a variation, since the bolt line is far enough to the right to be out of reach.

It may or may not be the same as route "G" in the Table Top main page. The crux is probably deciding where to stop and place your first pro - stances were good, so I ran it out until my feet were nearly at the height of
Kevin's
second bolt.
If
5.7 Dihedral
at Lookout Mountain Crag is a 5.7, then this is 5.6+ or 5.7- and flows enjoyably well. You should be able to TR off the anchors for
Kevin
location: Start in the slot for
Kevin Spies the Line
(see the picture from Mar. 14, 2010). Follow the crack up and left. Rappel from the anchors for
Kevin Spies the Line
protection: This was lead on small to medium nuts, one #3 Ballnut, and one larger nut (WC #8, I think). I didn't use any cams, may have used a Torque Nut. The line eats gear pretty well.

The first placement I decided to make was a WC #1, though if you want to place lower or higher you can use a different size pretty easily. If you have doubles of small nuts, then the Ballnut isn't needed.

description: Redrum climbs a chimney with interesting moves in its second half.  This second half contains a nice hand and finger crack.  The first half climbs blocky, easy terrain but the upper part makes the route worth doing at least once if you have trad gear at hand.
location: Redrum is about 15 feet left of
Henry Spies the Line
and is the next route left of
Sleeper
. It starts two or three feet left of
Sleeper
. Descend from the anchors on
Henry Spies the Line
protection: Standard rack.  Use the bolts on
Henry Spies the Line
for an anchor.

description: The crux is probably getting up the steep dihedral at the start, but the upper part of the crack is also steep and fun.  It would be harder, but it is littered with good horizontal holds.
location: This is the crack system just right of
Kevin Spies the Line
. You can get to the anchor on
Ian and Pat Spy Yet Another Easy Line
to rap off.
protection: Standard rack.  Only need a couple cams or nuts.  Build your own anchor (a little rotten up top). There are a couple textbook hex placements on the route.  Place em' if you got em' (can't get enough cow bells).

properties.0: Ian and Pat Spy Yet Another Easy Line

4.route_name: Ian and Pat Spy Yet Another Easy Line
description: Climb a left-facing slab past 2 bolts, pass the 2nd bolt on right (easier) or straight on (harder), and get established on a low angle slab and place gear while climbing to an obvious ledge. Step left of ledge and climb a clean face past 3 closely placed bolts to a chain anchor.
Per
curt86iroc
: for an alternate finish, leave the large ledge to the right and aim for the anchors on the neighboring route (
[Ian Murders Another Route
), clipping the last 3 bolts, 5.7. Watch for rope drag.
location: Reference the Haas and Schneider guidebook, page 74 topo, page 75. It is 10 feet right of
Kevin's Trad Line
protection: 5 bolts and gear to a #3 Camalot.

description: This is a relatively sustained route with solid ledge handholds and pockets.  Mounting the ledge beneath the anchors is a little trickier than it looks.
location: The set of bolts located between the
Mind Mantle Arete
and the
69.5 Crack
protection: 4 bolts plus anchors (
Eds. one is loose and wiggles

description: This route tackles the arete at the left end of the Tradlands where the cliff turns the corner into the gully/wash.  Scramble up to the base of the arete from the left.  Enjoyable moves on good stone run straight up the arete to the anchors.
protection: Three bolts to a two bolt anchor with rings.

description: Climb the crack system between "
Big O Flyer
" and "
X It
".  This crack system splits into two parallel cracks in places, and the climbing uses both cracks.
protection: Standard gear rack, and there is no fixed anchor on top.

properties.0: Last Stand of the Trad Lands
properties.4: {'route_name': 'Last Stand of the Trad Lands', 'grade': {'YDS': '5.7', 'French': '5a', 'Ewbanks': '15', 'UIAA': 'V+', 'ZA': '13', 'British': 'MVS 4b'}, 'safety': '', 'type': {'trad': True}, 'fa': 'unknown', 'description': ['Stem your way up the chimney while sharing a couple holds with the "', 'BM Route', '." As the chimney narrows, you\'ll find fun stemming footwork and shifting balance until you are in the choke point. Either climb directly up the nice open book with sparse protection or bail out left onto the mini-arete, and climb up to the final chimney that steepens before the top. Either clip the "', 'BM Route', '" bolts or search around for somewhere to build a trad anchor.', '', 'Beware of loose rock. There are a couple of chockstones that could move in the choke and some cross up high.'], 'location': ['This is the obvious chimney a couple feet left of the "BM Route" bolt line.'], 'protection': ['A standard rack, but it favors gear 0.2-0.75.'], 'metadata': {'left_right_seq': '13', 'parent_lnglat': [-105.21835, 39.76849], 'parent_sector': 'Trad Lands, The', 'mp_route_id': '118744584', 'mp_sector_id': '105745082'}}

4.fa: I. Altman, C. Brenon, K. Alinger, 1999
description: Climb the right side of a large block by doing short and well protected layback move (5.7). After surmounting block, leave a small ledge and climb arete past 5 bolts (5.7-). There is great exposure if you stay left and on the arete.
location: This route is just left of the "
Beehive Buttress
" and right of "
Arm and Hammer
" and the Red Rocks Simulator Wall.
protection: Gear: one 3.5" (#3 Camalot) is needed for the start, then 5 QDs to the 2 bolt anchor on top.

properties.4: {'route_name': "Caroline's OW", 'grade': {'YDS': '5.7', 'French': '5a', 'Ewbanks': '15', 'UIAA': 'V+', 'ZA': '13', 'British': 'MVS 4b'}, 'safety': '', 'type': {'trad': True}, 'fa': 'I. Altman and R. Nall, 10/25/15', 'description': ["This climb follows the obvious offwidth located on the far left side of the Box Elder Buttress. Begin with blocky hand cracks, and climb them for 20 feet before heading climber's right to enter the offwidth. The offwidth is sweet and has many features around it to make it just 5.7. This a great entry level offwidth, and it protects well too."], 'location': ["This route is locked to the far looker's left of the Box Elder Campground and 10 feet left of", "Caroline's Crack", '.'], 'protection': ['This mostly protects with hand-size cams, and you\'ll need two larger cams (#5 or #6 Camalot) for the offwidth section. You can protect the top of the off width with a 2" piece (either a #2 Friend of #1 Camalot).', '', 'There is a two bolt chained anchor up top.'], 'metadata': {'left_right_seq': '1', 'parent_lnglat': [-108.807, 37.8406], 'parent_sector': 'Dolores Canyon', 'mp_route_id': '111217518', 'mp_sector_id': '105896428'}}

{'route_name': "Caroline's Crack", 'grade': {'YDS': '5.7', 'French': '5a', 'Ewbanks': '15', 'UIAA': 'V+', 'ZA': '13', 'British': 'MVS 4b'}, 'safety': '', 'type': {'trad': True}, 'fa': 'I. Altman and J. Walsh, 10/2000', 'description': ['This climb follows the hand crack behind a flake that is located to the right of obvious OW crack (', "Caroline's Offwidth", '). Begin with ledgy blocks, and follow into sweet hand crack surrounded by good feet and rests. A subtitle crux move is near the top before the crack joints suddenly left to the anchor ledge.'], 'location': ['This route is located directly across the river from the Box Elder Campsite. It\'s on the far looker\'s left of the buttress or "Whiskey Wall".'], 'protection': ['Hand-size cams and a two bolt chain anchor up top.'], 'metadata': {'left_right_seq': '0', 'parent_lnglat': [-108.807, 37.8406], 'parent_sector': 'Dolores Canyon', 'mp_route_id': '111217432', 'mp_sector_id': '105896428'}}

description: This is a classic buildering route with strong tufa holds the whole way up that are securely attached to the building. In the past, it has been possible to squeeze through the locked top hatch on the roof, but you should be prepared to downclimb for the descent. It is pretty exposed to pizza eaters and is recommended that you climb this route at night.
location: This route is located on the corner of Colorado and Louisiana Avenue just behind Old Chicago Pizza on the back side of the apartments.
4101 E Louisiana Ave
Denver, Colorado
google.com/maps/place/4101+…
protection: No pro was used on the FA; however, you could sling the pipe above the attachment point for protection, but the strength rating is unknown. It is recommended that you are a strong leader before you attempt this route.

description: This is the wide crack to the right of
Volobee (aka Jolobee)
.  It is probably of
limited interest to most climbers
, but there are some offwidth bits that help you keep grounded.

Wander up easy scrambling or take the obvious arete (unprotected) to the base of the wide crack.  Move up the crack where you will find it harder if you use only crack technique.  Up near the top, the crack flares and begs you to armbar.  Top out on the ledge right of
Volobee (aka Jolobee)
location: This is to the right of
Volobee (aka Jolobee)
protection: Bring wide gear to possibly Bigbros or #5 (old style) Camalot or toprope it.

description: This ascends a hand crack around arete from
Left Slab
.  It is a good, short intro to hand crack climbing.
protection: Use #0.75 through #3 Camalots.  There are lower bolts at the top of the route.

properties.4: {'route_name': 'Thick Crust', 'grade': {'YDS': '5.7', 'French': '5a', 'Ewbanks': '15', 'UIAA': 'V+', 'ZA': '13', 'British': 'MVS 4b'}, 'safety': '', 'type': {'trad': True}, 'fa': 'unknown', 'description': ['This wide crack is right of the', 'Big Dihedral', 'and left of', 'The Virus', '.  Climb up to a "cave" and then exit with some precarious "looking" moves.  This climb has some fun finger jams and stems.  At the top, you can traverse right and use the bolt anchors on', 'The Virus', '.  It is #6 in the topo =>'], 'location': '', 'protection': ['Bring pro to 2" and several slings.  No fixed anchor.  Hubbel\'s said 4", but I never used it.'], 'metadata': {'left_right_seq': '37', 'parent_lnglat': [-105.2159, 39.76833], 'parent_sector': 'Brown Cloud Rocks', 'mp_route_id': '105757381', 'mp_sector_id': '105744702'}}

description: This is not too bad. The bolts may be out on the face, but most of the route is climbed on the far side of the arete. Basically follow the chalk up. There are lots of good resting points and confidence building holds.
Eds. note, the anchor is in a detached block.
protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.

description: Follow the crack that runs up and right, just right of
Killian's Dead
and
Deck Chairs
. Try to use only the crack at the top (crux), and not bail out to the dihedral corner on the right.
protection: Smaller cams, stoppers. We used a 20 foot sling thrown around a huge block.
Per
nathanjohnson83
: top bolts were recently added with a chain and a rap ring.

description: This is a decent little line 2 routes left of
Interface
.  It ascends a lieback to a short, right-facing dihedral.  It is often chalked up.
location: This is 2 routes left of
Interface
and just right of a chimney with 2 chockstones.
protection: A light rack to a #1 Camalot.  There is a 2 bolt Fixe anchor with rings that is shared with the route to the right.

description: This line takes the second crack system left of the "
Brown Cloud Arete

" (left of the crack with the prominent chockstone). Start in a shallow, right-facing corner that turns into a straight-in handcrack on the face above.  Belay on a good ledge on top, then walk off to the east.
Eds. note, you can traverse right to the anchor of
Brown Cloud Arête
and lower.
protection: Gear, no fixed anchor.

description: This is yet another short trad line to the left of
Protection From The Virus
.  It sort of oddly resembles
Belly Up
, but it is shorter and has more lichen and less jamming.  This probably will appeal to those who ask, "does that go?"

Move up a right-facing dihedral.  There is a large block which is likely fairly stable at its top.  The crack on the right looks more inviting from afar. Still it will accept yellow and red Aliens.  Move right and finish with some awkward moves.  There is an anchor bolt above which can be backed up by a #2 Camalot or by reaching down to the anchor bolts of
Protection From The Virus
You can walk off to the right.
location: This is to the left of
Protection From The Virus
protection: Cams yellow Alien to #4 Camalot.

description: This is a decent crack line to the right of
The Rodent

.  It utilizes a short, aesthetic corner on the left near its start.  Too bad that doesn't continue for the entire pitch.  Piece together stretches of crack, face holds, and top out at a 2 bolt anchor.
Thanks, Dan & Tom.  What did you name it?
location: This lies ~ 40 feet to the right of
The Rodent
around a small prow.
protection: Light rack to #0.75 Camalot.

description: This crack has certainly been climbed before but is not documented in any guide.  I am calling it Mousetrap due to its proximity to
The Rodent
.  The first 10', reaching a big ledge, are the most difficult.  Easy stemming on big holds then leads up the crack to the anchor.  This is a fun warm up climb if you have a rack with you.
location: This is the crack in the dihedral 6' to the right of
The Rodent
.  Descend from the anchors on
The Rodent
protection: Light standard rack to a #3 Camalot.  Use the bolt anchor on
The Rodent
to descend.

description: Climb a short crack into the chimney and find somewhat tricky, small gear in the thin crack on the left to protect a series of fun moves to the anchor.
location: This is in the chimney on the far right side of the East Quarry.
protection: Think thin, small Aliens, small offset Aliens, steel wires, Ballnuts,
etc.
up to finger-sized.  You might want something as large as a #4 Friend to protect the start.  Fixed ring anchors at the finish.

description: This is a good, wide crack on the right side of the area. It is fun and really easy.
location: Use the anchor for
S.S. Minnow
protection: A couple big Camalots.

4.fa: Dan Hare? Mike Cichone? Kirk Miller? Angus Wiessner?
description: This is a bulbous crack line that draws the eye as you walk from the Eastern approach to the East Quarry. It winds up being easier than it looks. The gear is smaller than you might expect. The crux is up high where it goes near vertical. There is a 2 bolt anchor up top.
Some may not consider this crack climbing.
location: This is to the right of
Emilia's Corner
and the bulk of the East Quarry routes. The bottom of the route is in a left-facing corner.
protection: Small cams to a #3 Camalot.

description: The route goes clockwise to almost a full 360 degrees to the summit. It's a fun way to summit. Rope drag can be an issue. so keep the rope loose. The rock is of poor quality, but it is a fun adventure off of I-70.
location: Start on east side, wrap clockwise.
protection: Small rack of cams up to 2" and webbing for anchors. Plan on replacing it as it is more of a lasso.

description: Climb up a left dihedral. The crux is halfway up. Don't let the corner pull you in, stem out.
location: This route is just left of
Early Start
protection: Traditional, it takes small gear and thins near the top. Save a #2 for the last move.

description: Climb the right corner crack to the top of the pillar, then finish with a fun hand jam.
location: Walk over to the far right of the First Wall
protection: Traditional, standard rack
No anchors, there is a tree just over the top of the climb, this can also be used for Wrong Crack.

metadata.parent_sector: Milk Creek (aka Wolcott Navajo Band - East)

description: If you know the name of this route, PM me, and I'll fix it!
Central Milk Creek.

Start with decent hands but some slippery feet to a good stance. Continue up with good jams and several rests. As you get near the top, you'll need to make a delicate step to the left, but it's easier than it appears from below.
location: This ascends the right side of the central apron with visible anchors on top.
protection: A standard rack.

metadata.parent_sector: Milk Creek (aka Wolcott Navajo Band - East)

description: This is the route to the right of Plumber's Crack on the arete.  It is just to the right of where the main approach trail reaches the rock.
Consistent climbing up the arete or left face up a nice ramp.  Stemming to the left easing things.  Two bolts are on the right side of the arete and kind of easy to miss.
protection: 4 bolts to anchors.

description: The whole route is good!
location: It shares chains with
Ecstacy
protection: Medium to large cams.

description: This is a fun layback, and you can also jam your feet. Try handjamming, but you’ll likely find it’s too painful due to the pebbly nature of the rock. The crux is up top, especially if you decide to top out.
location: It is located at the dihedral near large boulder. This ascends the large, obvious crack with a nice, flat base.
protection: A bouldering pad.

Also, this is fun to place gear on if you want, it protects well the whole way up but gets progressively wider. The bottom is around a #0.75 or #1. At the top, you get either a tipped out #4 that you need to look around for a good enough placement or a #5 (which would be preferred). A TR anchor can be made using crack to the left up top if you extend it over to this route, placing a large cam to redirect and hold masterpoint in place is a good idea to prevent masterpoint from sliding out of crack.

description: Start in the left-facing dihedral and move up through the crux.  Continue up the ledge system to the top.
Walk off to the South.
protection: Standard rack.

description: Start at the base of
Coroner's Crack
, but take the right hand crack system, topping out to the right.

This is a great route for beginner trad climbers.  It is a fun climb with large, obvious, easy to place pro from good solid rests.  The crux is in the middle section and is initially puzzly for its grade, thus the (+).  Watch for some of the ever-present cactus on the top.
I'm sure we're not the real FA, but this route is not named in Hanson's '99 revision guide.
location: This uses the same start as
Coroner's Crack
, left of the Labor Day/
Jerry's Kids
face.
protection: Mostly larger pieces.  I used hexes & a 2.5 tri-cam.

description: Follow the climber's trail south from the Grocery Store Walls until finding a big roof in the Neanderthal area.  The climb goes up the big dihedral to the right of the big roof.  Climb up to the ledge where you can climb the dihedral, protecting the thin cracks with small nuts or you can layback the flake, protecting  yourself with larger pieces.
protection: Bring a few large pieces if pulling the flake or some some small nuts if doing the dihedral.

description: This route goes up the obvious flake on the left face of the chimney to the right of '
Fat Fingered and Overhung

'. I've seen chalk all [about] the base of this route but not higher up. I'm certain I'm not the first ascentionist, but I am claiming it, unless otherwise corrected.... It is a nice little route, a little exposed, but most climbers will breeze it.
location: This is just to the [left] of the
Ada Jam
route.
protection: This route can be easily top roped using some longer webbing and the trees on top... some small nuts on top for back up....
If you want to lead this trad, I'd suggest some larger (7-9 hexes) pieces for the crack, [but] either way, there is risk of a pendulum into the chimney face.

description: This climb is not in the guidebook.  A fellow climber pointed it out as we were passing by.  He was not sure of the name, but he thought it was called Hanson's Folly.  Maybe Mr. Hanson knows the truth.

Anyway, climb a face with a crack on the left to a ledge.  From here, it is class 1 to class 3 to the chimney.  Climb the chimney to the overhanging offwidth (crux).  Figure out the crux and follow the crack and slab to the top.
location: Hanson's Folly is a little further southeast from
Primal Jam
.  Look for a chimney and an offwidth crack (see photo).

There are multiple options for the descent.  There is a class 4 descent to the south near the start of the Cave Wall and at least three class 4 descents to the north before you get to the Grocery Store Wall.
protection: Standard rack plus I used a #4 BD and #5 Friend at the crux.

4.fa: from Tom Hansen's Climbers Guide to Castlewood
description: The crack right of
Pack the Walls
, in the same chimney.
protection: TR - you could lead it with small pro if you are bold.  In a pinch, you can stem out the the detached block that forms a cave.  I happened to stroll through the cave and see a colony of bats about a foot from my head.

4.fa: from Tom Hansen's Climber's Guide to Castlewood
description: Climb the right-facing corner crack between
Oof Roof
and
March of the Druids
protection: TR or trad.

metadata.parent_sector: Realm of the Venusian Love Goddess

description: Find the second next inside corner system to the right of
Magic Mountain
.  There is a boulder/flake at the base of this route.  Climb up through the crack with very few positive holds up high.
protection: Standard rack. A #3 Friend fits into the wide middle section.

metadata.parent_sector: Realm of the Venusian Love Goddess

4.fa: [R. Hanson, N. Bertols, M. Skapyak, L. Ankle]
description: Going North from the downclimb (and detached block). Find the second major chimney system and climb the dihedral to the left of it.  This is the third or fourth inside corner.
protection: Standard rack.

metadata.parent_sector: Realm of the Venusian Love Goddess

description: The next chimney/ crack to the right of the bolted roof  and bolted face offers an interesting lead.  Start off with a tricky move to get onto the route, climb past some wide spots, and make a committing layback off the flake. Topping out is also interesting.  Caution!  There is a loose block or two hiding in the recesses of the chimney.  Also be a little wary of the flake which didn't inspire great amounts of confidence in me.
protection: Standard rack- including some larger pieces like some big (8,9,10) hexes and Friends (#3-4).

metadata.parent_sector: Realm of the Venusian Love Goddess

description: In the corner of the Falls Wall directly above the Buoux Block is the climb.  The lower section is hard to protect with the crux being getting to the large pocket and thus the flake.  The flake above (easier) is very aestetic and takes a few good cams.  Lieback on the flake as much as you want!  The start I took is the feature on the far right that is shaded.  The crux is getting to the big pocket (left of the tree)  The flake is hidden in this pic but obvious from any other angle.
protection: The bottom is tricky to protect.  I used a large nut in a constricting crack/pocket.  The upper flake takes some small to medium cams.  Setting up an anchor is ploblematic.  I used the bolts to the N with a good directional.

description: Start on the far right side of the columns and ascend the RHS of the face.  It is not a bad route, but it is not as good as the direct line.
protection: Complicated TR setup, with one 1/4" bolt.

description: This climb is on the inside of The Grotto and goes up the thin dihedral on the inner N facing wall.  Begin the route by climbing up to the dihedral on the face as well as the small roof.  The climb follows the dihedral, offering thin jams and pro opportunities.
protection: A few small small pieces protect the climb while some additional gear/slings is needed for the top anchor.

description: Left of a smooth wall at the middle of the Morning Sun Wall is a series of cracks and flakes that makes an interesting lead.  Start off on the smooth wall under the climb and surmount a ledge.  There are a few harder unprotectable  face climbing moves right off the deck if you take a direct start.  Otherwise you could start on the first shelf and traverse to the climb.  There are several old, manky,  hangerless bolts along the climb.  Follow the cracks and flakes up taking whatever line you choose.
protection: Bring a standard rack.  Setting up an anchor on top might be tricky but you could use the bolted anchors on the next climb to the left (S).

description: The Sky is Falling is a nice route with a little bit of all types of climbing. The first 10-15 feet is small crimpers. Then it moves to some really nice, easy jugs, over past the ledge onto the flake. Then there is a nice balance move to the top. The crux is probably the balance move. It's a pretty simple yet fun route.
location: This is located 15 feet left of
Entry Level
on a black streak. It is easily recognizable by the flake halfway up.
protection: A rack of nuts. It can be toproped by running a 30' cord around the negative space on the boulder directly above it.

description: This route is in the clean, left-facing book corner to the west of the Rat cracks.  The climb is partially hidden from below by some boulders below it.  It is a clean corner with good pro, providing a great moderate lead especially for Castlewood.
protection: Standard trad rack up to #2 cam

metadata.parent_sector: Coat of Arms Corner and The Rat Cracks

description: There is a slab face to the right of
Freeway
that gives you yet another line to climb during your visit to Mill Creek Crag.  It was mentioned somewhere in Harald's writeup.  To flesh it out, we'll list it as a separate entry.
Climb up just to the right of
Freeway

, and move up the face connecting discontinuous features with small gear.  From the ledge, you can continue up to the left in the shallow, right-facing corner or go up the double crack system with the old Bugaboo pin.  Note, the rock further to the right of the pin looks less difficulty, but it is fairly licheny.
location: This is just to the right of
Freeway's
dihedral by a few feet.
protection: Small gear up to a #1 Camalot.
Note, there is no fixed anchor on the ledge 40 feet up.

description: MargaSukha is P1 of a two pitch route and is labeled "D" in the photo. Expect mostly easy climbing on solid stone. Most of these new routes have been completed, cleaned, and are quite fun. Two of the pitches remain projects as of 3/20/2012. P2 above MS (F) is very difficult but open to anyone wishing to try a burn.
location: It is in the middle of the right side.
protection: A good range of cams from 1/4 inch to 2.5 inch. Some of this gear goes into horizontal letter box slots. Double bolt anchor at the top for a short rap.

properties.4: {'route_name': 'Shattered', 'grade': {'YDS': '5.7', 'French': '5a', 'Ewbanks': '15', 'UIAA': 'V+', 'ZA': '13', 'British': 'MVS 4b'}, 'safety': '', 'type': {'sport': True}, 'fa': 'Matthias Holladay', 'description': ['Climb small edges, layaways, and jugs up to a nice ledge.'], 'location': '', 'protection': ['2 bolts and pro to 1/2\x81\x8d".'], 'metadata': {'left_right_seq': '2', 'parent_lnglat': [-107.88289, 37.25538], 'parent_sector': 'Smelter Gulch', 'mp_route_id': '110361936', 'mp_sector_id': '109112930'}}

description: Follow edges and slopers up low angle slab.
protection: Bolts.

description: Climb pink rock and a green, lichened face. Stay on the arete' for a more exposed challenge (maybe 5.8) or use lower angled slope to the left. It is a great warm-up! Look out of stinging nettles at the base :-)
location: The route is easy to spot from the main area below
Winnebago Warrior
and
Euro Vision
. It faces east and has a beautiful mosaic of lime green lichen and pink quartzite.
protection: 7 bolts.

properties.4: {'route_name': 'Bananas and Blow', 'grade': {'YDS': '5.7', 'French': '5a', 'Ewbanks': '15', 'UIAA': 'V+', 'ZA': '13', 'British': 'MVS 4b'}, 'safety': '', 'type': {'tr': True}, 'fa': 'unknown', 'description': ['Start on the left side of the slab.\xa0Some good dirty moves bring you up to a left-facing flake, and follow the flake up into the void. Your palms then get you to the top. Traverse right to the anchor.'], 'location': ['It is on the left side of the NE slab.'], 'protection': ['This shares an anchor with the bolted routes on the slab.', '', 'Per', 'Spencer Cone', ': there are bolts and an anchor now.'], 'metadata': {'left_right_seq': '5', 'parent_lnglat': [-107.88331, 37.31023], 'parent_sector': 'Cube, The', 'mp_route_id': '114222190', 'mp_sector_id': '114075280'}}

description: Climb up rock which looks SO loose, but is really solid (sort of)... this begins on a long diagonal seam up and left of fractured, but pretty good rock...get to a stance under a fin, and go over roof, right into dihedral, up this, move left onto narrow face of huge arête and up left of roofs to the top.
location: This is on the last flat section to chill before rounding the corner to the cove. Start left of huge block perched to the right under an obvious, big dihedral.
protection: Small wires to 3"...TR for now, it still needs more pro & cleaning.

description: This is not too bad for an initial foray. We ended up rapping it to avoid climbing past death blocks. This has good rock, once cleaned.
location: Start from the boulder under the roof.
protection: The smallest wires to 4".

description: Climb the angling wide crack and chimney with a few interesting moves.
location: The right side of
The Gullies
.  The wide crack is pretty obvious.
protection: Typically done as a toprope.

description: Climb through an initial wide section, angling left towards the center of the X.  Then angle back right, ending at a stance at the top of the crack.
location: This is on the right side of the south face.
protection: Standard rack with possibly a larger piece.

description: This is a good, moderate, face climb with some cool features. Three bolts with a fairly moderate yet long run-out at the top lead you to a two bolt anchor.
location: Oxbow is the furthest route right on the Dos XX cliff.
protection: Three new bolts. There is a solid new anchor at the top.

description: This is a fun, short climb at the start with much easier climbing at the top.
location: It is just to the right from
Diagonal Dihedral
protection: You need trad gear, I toproped from the pine tree at the top.

description: This is an easy face climb just right of
Elementary Corner
protection: TR.

description: Climb a thin crack to a face and the top.
location: It is the 1st route from the trail.
protection: Bolts and gear to 2".

description: Go up to a dish with a good bulge, get a pocket out left, then climb holds back right to the top.
protection: Bolts.

description: Climb the chimney / face at South end of the slot.
location: Gain the slot for this chimney/face/arête climb by rapping in after stepping over the void onto the pillar proper, or tunnel/chimney from the east.
protection: TR.

description: Climb the dirty, low-angle groove to the steeper and cleaner offwidth crack. Finish at a bolted anchor.
location: Past most of the routes, go up the hill on the right end of the cliff, this is the obvious wide crack.
protection: #4 - #6 Camalot.

description: Like
Wildflower
, it's another good, beginner, sport route.
location: This is just to the right of
Wildflower
protection: 3 bolts.

description: Easy ledges leads R to small ledge then moves further R and up.
protection: TR.

description: Up R side of arete, face leads to arete/corner moves and then wide crack of
Manta Ray Ride
location: Just to the R of
Manta Ray Ride
protection: TR

description: Start as for
Manta Ray Ride
, then awkward mantle L into corner. Sharp aretes and clean jugs lead up then traverse R to top anchor of
Manta Ray Ride
location: Start left of Small Aretes leading down from top of cliff.
protection: Standard rack. The pro is often to the left or right of climbing, and so a fall must be avoided.

description: Shale start to double cracks, L across jugs under roof to small nook belay, (L to
Broken Mast
) 2nd pitch move R past the base of
Captain Joel
with horizontals to arete, bulge to gray face, past
Captain Matthias
thin crack. Past this RO traverse- bolts, wide pro in pocket- to cracks in small ramp leading up to anchor.
protection: Pro/bolts, anchor at top.

description: Easy flakes to ledge and blunt aretes, traverse R to devious pocket and top.
location: This is the L side of a big, R-facing book, the L side of the cove.
protection: Bolts/pro/anchor.

description: Shale start to double cracks, L across jugs under roof to small nook belay, 2nd pitch, (L to Broken Mast) move R past the base of Captain Joel with horizontals to arete, bulge to gray face, to the next thin L diagonaling crack R of a black water streak. Continue up this, or belay again in cracks on ramp to reduce rope drag.
protection: Pro/needs anchor.

description: Start w/ crack splitting horizontals to flake and bulge, thin crack at top.
location: Just L of Jake's Gully, scramble up through bushes to little ledge at base.
protection: Pro/bolts.

description: Three sets of roofs: a black, horizontal crack w/ small tree roof to start, a short, vertical section then turn another roof to flared slot and thin crack to roof with blocks and vertical crack to finish.
Schiavone and Middleton attempted to free the route and bailed, putting anchor past second set of roofs.
location: The start of this route is back in the deepest part of Khumbu's Cove.
protection: A standard aid rack.

description: From same big ledges as in
Clicking Barnacles
, climb L of stacked blocks to ledge at large corner, move L onto face and anchors. Beware death block perched in dihedral at top.
location: R of
Clicking Barnacles
protection: Bolts/pro.

description: This is a nice flake to....
protection: Pro to 2".

description: Climb the crack on left to moves right under the flake up to the top.
protection: Pro to 2".

description: Belay from nice notch between Juniper tree and cliff. Ascend crack R of dihedral and corner. Traverse R at end to reach anchor of
Our Tidal Surge
. The two TR's of Grog Supply, L & R, are on the face and arete to the right respectively. These would make excellent leads.
location: Start up from notch next to juniper tree.
protection: Standard rack.

description: Climb flakes in a corner to a dirty hold then undercling up and over bulges with good stances, cracks for pro, & to the anchor.
location: This is on the left side of outcrop. There's a direct start right under the corner, or an easier one coming in from the left.
protection: 2 bolts / 1 or 2 smaller-sized Aliens and/or some smaller to medium-sized wired nuts.

description: Jeanette's ascends a nice crack system in dihedral with face holds on either side. Exit left to anchors of
Girls on Stage
or right to anchors of
Elanor's
location: This is the corner/crack system between
Girls on Stage
and
Elanor's
protection: Small cams and wires.

description: Edges to small, left-facing corner, up to good stances then left and over steeper moves to ledge.
location: Clean vertical face to the left of the Chipette Overhang.
protection: Red Camalot, small wired / bolts.

description: Traverses left past two cracks and bolt, then up trending right over big holds to top with anchors out right.
location: Begins at far right of overhang.
protection: Pro / fp / bolt.

description: Sabine's Magical Mystery Tour shares the same start with
Petra's Wild Ride
, but traverse left at the ledge. (Alternately, flake and mantle on the left lead to ledge.) From here, aesthetic moves up a crack, then go right on jugs and over a bulge to the anchor.
protection: Bolts/small rack.

description: Shallow corner leads to a flake and ledge. Go right and over a roof to the anchor.
location: This is the first route you come to after traversing along the base.
protection: Bolts/small rack.

description: These are good short climbs.  There is a two-bolt face on the left; to the right a nice dihedral and cracks up through slot, protected with small to medium wires.
protection: Bolts / nuts.

description: Traverse left 25 ft (5.5) from the start of
Unrelenting Undertow
to belay. Climb black face split by cracks or as a variation huge hollow flakes and blocks on the right. Needs cleaning.
location: This route is around the corner left of
Unrelenting Undertow
. It's accessed by dropping down and around to the left for a dicy loose start. At the notch of the huge shady conifer just below the Bowsprit area and the route
Pink Medusa
, find the wire and stump of the old fence line in the talus and contour here. Go under the juniper to reach the base of the loose start.
protection: Standard rack.

metadata.parent_sector: A. Edge of the World Area

description: Head straight up from ledge of
Pink Medusa
in crack slanting up, then L onto face and arete to thin crack and anchor.
protection: Pro/bolt.

description: Climb lower-angle rock past 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
location: This is the [sixth] route from the right, second to last before the fence.
protection: 5 (now 10-11) bolts.

description: This aesthetic arête has two options to choose from. The original route climbs the right side of the arête. Start at the base of the arête for full value. Alternately, begin in corner and get pro in a pocket then left to arête and up.
location: This ascends the right side of the sharp arête.
protection: Bring a Tri-cam for the pocket if you start from the corner, 4 bolts if you start from the base of the arête proper. This adds a few nice moves to the route.

description: Climb the arete & the face to the left of the arete.
location: About 25 feet right of
Pebbles
is a sharp arete, the left side of the arete is Chattanooga Choo Choo.
protection: Four bolts to chains.

description: This is probably the [2nd] longest route on the cliff.  Climb past 11 bolts (formerly 6) to a 2 bolt anchor.
location: To the right of the fence there are several routes, this is the rightmost route of this cluster.
protection: This originally had 6 bolts. As of July 2014, there are now 11 bolts.

description: As the name implies, this route marks the end of the climbing at East Animas. Start with a few steep moves off the ground then lieback, jam, and stem up the nice left-facing corner to a large chockstone. Move right or left around the chockstone to lower angle terrain, then make a couple steeper moves to the anchor. Finish at bolts.
location: This is at the far left end of the climbing at East Animas.
protection: Blue Metolius - #2 or #3 Camalot, and small - medium stoppers.

description: This is a nice moderate that protects and climbs well. Climb the hand and finger crack past a tree, then finish up with steep, juggy, and fun moves to a bolted anchor.
location: Start 10 feet left of
Yosemite Crack
at some large boulders.
protection: Standard East A rack - #3 Camalot.
Per
Ben Kiessel
there is now a 2 bolt anchor.

description: Go up a slab start off the deck, then continue up the easy and aesthetic dihedral with a short traverse left to the anchors at the top.
Eds. Per
KJS
: this is on private land.  All land to the right of the East Animas designated climbing trail is on private land.  Please respect their request to not climb here.  Thanks.
location: This is right of
Sun Burn
, further to the right of the alcove. Past a little buttress and clean face, it's a dihedral with a slab start.
protection: Bolt at the slab, then gain the dihedral; good pro to 4 inches up the corner.

description: This route is located on the far right side of the cliff.
location: This is on the far right side of the cliff.
protection: Three bolts, pro to 1.5 inches, anchors.

description: This route climbs the obvious, right-leaning crack on the right side of the cliff.
location: This is the crack on the right side of the cliff.
protection: Pro to 3 inches.

description: This is the easiest route leading to the top of the
Apple Cider
area and I think is most often done as an approach to
The Overview
.  It starts up a crack that leads to a right-angling ramp feature.  From the top of the ramp, move into a left-facing corner and take it to the top.
location: Right side of the Apple Cider area, just to the right of
Punta Magna
protection: Standard rack.

properties.0: Charlie's Indirect (submitted as Travels With Charlie)
properties.4: {'route_name': "Charlie's Indirect (submitted as Travels With Charlie)", 'grade': {'YDS': '5.7', 'French': '5a', 'Ewbanks': '15', 'UIAA': 'V+', 'ZA': '13', 'British': 'MVS 4b'}, 'safety': '', 'type': {'trad': True}, 'fa': 'Michael Borga & ?', 'description': ['P1 - start the same as', 'Easy to Remember', ', then go up a right-angling ramp past a ledge to a belay behind a large boulder.', '', 'P1 Variation - do a more direct finger crack start that meets up with the right-angling ramp (5.9).', '', 'P2 - traverses to the left on a sloping ledge and moves around a corner.', '', 'Per', 'Michael Borga', ': the line shown and listed here is what we called "Charlie\'s Indirect!"', '', '"Travels with Charlie" went straight up and over the boulder where the first belay station is achieved. We called the p1 variation in the description "Charlie\'s Direct".'], 'location': ['The start is the same as that of', 'Easy To Remember', '.  To the right of', 'Texas Sucks', 'and left of', 'Apple Cider', '.'], 'protection': ['Standard East A rack.'], 'metadata': {'left_right_seq': '6', 'parent_lnglat': [-107.836, 37.3183], 'parent_sector': 'Apple Cider', 'mp_route_id': '105832145', 'mp_sector_id': '105821642'}}

description: P1 - start up the corner, move right and follow the broken crack system to a bolted anchor near a large tree.
Variation: towards the top of the pitch, take the offwidth on the right and finish at the same anchor.
P2 - climb the smaller crack on the right with a small tree in it.
Variation - climb the offwidth on the left which rejoins the standard line.
location: This route starts in a right-facing corner a little to the left of
Byrd's Classic
protection: Standard East A rack - #3 Camalot. Bring a big cam if doing either of the OW variations.

description: This is an easy route that is good for beginners.  It climbs a slabby face with cracks and a bolt.
location: The start is the same as that of
Jabba the Hut Levitates
protection: Standard East A rack.

description: Climb the slab start of
Sunshine

and move right on sweet jugs across a rail to beautiful in-cuts and liebacks up blunt arête. Go up this on even nicer edges to a good horizontal crack & easier lower-angled moves past a little tree ledge bulge; friction up slab below the top.
Eds. Per
KJS
: this is on private land.  All land to the right of the East Animas designated climbing trail is on private land.  Please respect their request to not climb here.  Thanks.
location: Use the
Sunshine
start, then traverse right and up.
protection: Pro to 1", bolts, two bolt anchor.

description: This is a bolted sport climb.
Per
James Hicks
: 6 Bolts, located just left of the "Behind the Fridge" open book dihedral.
location: This is the 1st route on the left.
protection: Bolts.

description: This is super fun!
location: Access: there is a climber's trail just below
Drill for the Thrill
. Please follow this to the base of the crag, then traverse left. This means a couple of extra steps but will save the talus slope from erosion.
The start is just left and below the pillar in the middle of the Prow.
See the
The Prow topo.
for location.
protection: 7 bolts.

description: A fun warm-up gives way to awkward traverse. Folks should know these easy routes are on this side of the canyon.
location: Walk past
Turds
and
Bam
a couple hundred yards. After you see
Honeymoon
(with a little painted stone at the base), go around one more corner to get to Summer Shuffle and
Mouse
(also with their own painted rocks).
protection: 11 bolts, anchor

description: This route has interesting climbing that traverses a bit linking up easier features. The crux is at a bulge, and the easiest moves are right of the bolt.
location: It is climber's left of
Grand Avenue
, up a small steep hill. This is the first of three bolted lines after the small hill.
protection: Bolts and a two bolt anchor.

description: This is a broken and varied, mostly finger-sized crack with lots of face features to use as well. The crack can be a little dirty from runoff.
location: This is towards the Pool. It is to the right of
One Summer's Eve
. It is pretty easy to spot the crack.
protection: Finger-sized cams and stoppers.

description: To be edited in.
location: From the beta photo, this is the 4th route (L->R).
protection: Gear.
To be edited in.

description: This is easier than
West Ridge
and less committing.
location: Again, start at the belay alcove, enjoy the beautiful traverse out to the micro dihedral of
West Ridge
, and ascend but trend right at its top to another bolt.
protection: 2 bolts plus small wires.

description: Start as with
Joan's Solitude
, but ease up and right to a large flake that takes a medium nut. Then step up to gain the slab and clip bolts as you climb staying to the right side of the slab.
location: It was the farthest right on the slab.
Per
Dave Clark 5.10
: it is in the middle of the slab and goes up a rough, left-facing dihedral.
protection: 6-7 (perhaps 5?) bolts, 1 medium wired nut needed.
Per
Dave Clark 5.10
: there are no spinning hangers as of 7/4/18.

description: Moose Glades has fairly decent face climbing up into the dihedral.
location: From the cozy little belay alcove with pine tree, traverse out right (west) to find the rising bolts to the right of
Salto Syllabic
, aiming for a bush and left-facing corner that rounds over into a ledge.
protection: 2 bolts with nuts as needed.

description: This is the first route on the slab that was toproped and then bolted. Use the tree as needed or go stone direct. An optional left side start also works.
location: It is on the far right side of the slab, directly behind a pine tree.
protection: 6-7 bolts (perhaps 5?) plus one small wired nut and one medium wired nut are required.

description: The guidebook rates this 5.8, but even with my short time on the rock, I can't bring myself to agree. It's a fun moderate, great if you're looking to learn lead, and the view up top is fantastic. The route starts on a right-trending ramp that you can nearly walk up before getting into some more interesting moves for the grade.
A 70m rope is required.
location: This route is a short jaunt after Smarter than the Average Bear and Daydream. Follow the trail down through a million or more aggressive thistles until the rock falls away from you on your left. The first 3 bolts are easily spotted on a very light grade about ten to fifteen feet left of some bushes. You might have trouble seeing the rest of the bolts until you start climbing, but rest assured they're all there, somewhere.
protection: 12 hundred bolts to a couple snazzy anchors.

description: Start in a shallow, right-facing corner, climbing up good crimps leading to the anchors.
protection: 5 bolts to anchors.

description: This is a long, sustained ridge climb with moderate exposure. The majority of the route is easy 5th class with only a few areas of true 5.7 climbing. Its rock quality is marginal with some loose stuff especially towards the upper section.
location: This ascends Mt. Crested Butte, looker's right of Banana Funnel and one ridge to looker's right of Guide's Ridge.
protection: Nuts, small cams through #3 Camalot, lots of runners for slinging horns. A 40 meter rope worked out well. There are no anchors.

4.fa: Stewart Green, Martha Morris, and Mike Heinrichs, Sept. 2004
description: From the guidebook: Excellent moderate route on the right side of the face.  Begin by scrambling up to a 1-bolt anchor in a scoop below central wall.  Traverse right on third class rock for 60 feet to a bolt at a small belay stance.  Smear up the undulating slab above to a headwall.  Work up right along a line of flakes to a hole with a large crystal-line xenolith ("strange rock").  Anchors are on a narrow shelf above.
Caution: The flake towards the top is loose.
location: This route is the farthest right route on Wiggins' Wall.  You can find it from the shady area by scrambling up the rock and traversing (approximately 60 feet) to the right, you'll see the belay bolt roughly 30-45 feet from the dirt line (bear in mind erosion may increase this distance).  It's definitely decent 3rd class hiking to get there.  The anchors when you look at the rock will be just to the left of the bushes that have a small outcropping below them.
protection: 8 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor (there is a belay bolt as well, and it's pretty high up and could be mistaken to the first bolt).

description: This route is just South of
Smear Campaign
. There are bolts right where you need them. It is a good route that seems to be getting just a bit harder than its original rating.
location: Scramble up to a 1 bolt anchor in a scoop below the central wall. Book says to rap with double ropes or a 60 meter, but a 70 meter works better.
protection: 10 bolts with 3 bolt anchor.

description: This route starts from the top of the wicked triangular flake in the middle of Old Ironsides Slab, straight up to and over the arch to the 1st. belay of
E. Boy
. Face and friction.
location: Old Ironsides Slab. Decent-either finish with
E. Boy
or
Keelhauled
or rap with 2 ropes.
protection: Small wires? cam? in the arch.

4.fa: Stewart Green, Mike Heinrichs, Martha Morris
description: This is a corner system (yes - an actual corner/crack at RRCOS) on the left side of the face. Head straight up to first bolt, then work your way into the corner system from left hand side up past third bolt to small ledge. Proceed straight up as slab tapers off to anchors.
location: This is the leftmost climb of three at the Whale's Tail.
protection: 6 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.

4.fa: Brian Shelton and Stewart Green, August 2004
description: This is a short sport route with a crux between the 1st and 2nd bolt.
location: The route is the second bolted route from the right on the Solar Slab.  It starts just left of a large juniper tree then climbs up and left to the anchors.
I recommend buying Stewart Green's Red Rocks guidebook at the Garden of the Gods Visitor's Center for complete route descriptions and maps of all routes.
protection: 4 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.

description: A. Climb the finger crack, there are slots for BD nuts sized 4-8. (5.6+)
B. Climb through some loose flakes and slabs, there are slots for cams around #1 BD. (5.6)
C. Use the crack of this large flake to place a piece for the traverse over to the true route. Use a #10 BD nut, or a #2 cam.

D. The traverse is 10-15 feet long, climb slightly down as you cross.  There are some good ledges and flakes for your feet; you can swing out a leg to cross into the crack system.  A fall would be very uncomfortable but not severe. (5.7)

E. There is an ancient pin that is fairly well placed.  There are a few balancy moves. . This is a good place for an anchor.  There is a slot for a size 13 nut, and some small cams #.75 and a Metolius cam size #1 and 2.

F. The moves bringing you over the bulge is the crux. A medium cam can protect the moves. A #5 Metolius fits better than a BD cam, but you can use either a .75 or a 1 if you only have BD.  It is a good idea to extend the pieces to reduce rope drag.  Once you pull through the harder moves you can throw a beautiful #2 BD into a slot and move on to comfort. (5.7+)

G. There are a few slab moves up to an excellent lay back finger crack.  You can throw in some great nuts.  If you don't have a 70-meter rope, pause here for an anchor.  Keep working up the layback and place a good nut at the top. Work up onto the easy slab with face climbing, above here the pro gets a little scarce. (5.6)

H. The slab and face moves are easy but fun.  Look out for a good micro nut placement, and then work up to the top.  There are 25 feet of 5.5 slab that cannot be protected, and then the climb turns into 4th class terrain.  The last 100 feet are unprotectable.  Once you get to the top you will see a huge bolder.  Throw a couple cams in the crack at the bottom, or just sling the whole thing for an anchor. (5.5)  [If you have a shorter rope MAKE SURE YOU SET AN ANCHOR WITHIN 25 METERS OF THE LAST ONE. The dome rounds out and the last 20-25 meters are unprotectable so if you get stuck up there you are pretty nicely screwed.]
DESCENT.  Walk right (North) and down until you find a tree to rap down off of. You will need two ropes. You can also down climb a 5.5 slab to the ground, though a fall would surely result in injury.
protection: Bring a set of BD Camalots .4-3.5, or 1-8 Metolius, as well as a full set of stoppers.

The pro at the end (last 100 feet) is next to none but other than that, you can throw something in every 7-10 feet.  On the first pitch, the gear may be slightly questionable because there are some expanding flakes.

4.fa: unknown -- probably Stewart Green and/or Brian Shelton
description: This is the top-rope route immediately right of
El Sol

The bottom one-third is almost pure friction climbing on some pretty slick sandstone.  It is listed in Stewart Green's Red Rock guidebook as 5.7, but I thought the bottom third of Frigga was definitely tougher than anything on
Helios
(5.7+) which is two routes left.  It is worth a climb after doing
El Sol
location: This line goes to the farthest right anchors on Solar Slab.
Climb
El Sol
, then once on top traverse right 15 feet from
El Sol
anchors to set the top-rope on the two Frigga anchors.
I recommend buying Stewart Green's Red Rocks Guidebook at Garden of the God's visitor's center for complete Red Rocks route descriptions/locations.
protection: There is a 2-bolt anchor at top but no protection beneath.
Per
Stewart M. Green
: there no bolts on this route. There never has been any lead bolts on it.

4.fa: Stewart Green, Brian Shelton, Mike Heinrichs
description: This line has excellent slab climbing. Start with careful smearing straight up past three bolts to small ledge. After the ledge, the moves through 4th bolt provide more handholds.
location: This is the first route north of
Tempest Toast
. There is a nice large tree at base to mark start of route - can also serve as belay anchor if needed.
protection: 4 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.
Per
Paul Vervalin
: the anchor bolts have been moved up.  It is now ~110'.

4.fa: Stewart Green, Martha Morris, and Mike Heinrichs, September 2004
description: From the guidebook: Another great moderate. Climb a slab to a finishing headwall.
location: From guidebook: Reach the face by hiking south from where the north cliff access trail reaches the cliff. Hike along the cliff-base until the trail crosses a low angle slab shaded by a large juniper tree.
Routes #7 to #11 were described as: below a clean slab composed of two different sandstone layers.
Other notes: This route is the 11th developed route on the Whale and number #11 in the guidebook.
Addendum: there is a crux move near the top that will be harder for shorter climbers.
protection: bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.
Per
Paul Vervalin
: the anchor bolts have been moved up.  It is now ~110'.

description: This is a nice climb with 2 distinct cruxes.  The first one pulls through a short bulge past two bolts. Then you climb a pretty long runout, up and right, to a steep slab with nice crimps and two more bolts.  I gave the PG-13 rating, because if you were to fall prior to clipping the third bolt, it could bounce you off the flatter section of rock and possibly leave you with an injury, but this isn't too bad, and the route is still worth climbing.
location: This route is on the south end of the Whale, above Never-Ever Slab.  From the narrow ledge above Never-Ever Slab, there is a small juniper tree on the left end of the ledge.  This route is the third one right of the tree (the first two are
Dreamtime
and
Aborigine
, respectively).  Guide info from Stewart Green's publication.
protection: 4 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.

4.fa: Brian Shelton, Mike Heinrichs, Stewart Green
description: Easy climbing with some interesting moves to headwall (more of a bulge)... then a simple walk up past final bolt to anchors. Climb up a series of steps to and past bolt 2. For the easiest line, begin traversing right at bolt 3 and then go staight up and over using some large diagonal ledges.
location: Right side of a large tree on the base trail of Whale (route # 17 in Stewart Green's book). The tree is the first big one left of the landmark thin pine.
protection: 6 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.

description: This is a nice 5.7 route, but it is a bit sketchy for new leaders. Smear and look for good feet to a high first bolt. Pull left to begin 'S' Curve. Once you clip second bolt, use foot holds on the left side of gully to walk up with some friction assistance from your right in the dihedral. As move to third bolt, work right work right using good, high feet. Walk up a slightly run-out slab to anchors.
location: This is just left of the pine tree in middle of the Whale (route #16 in Stewart Green's book).
protection: 5 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.

4.fa: Brian Shelton, Mike Heinrichs, and Stewart Green, Sept 2004
description: Climb a shallow, right-facing corner (protect with a #2 Camalot) and stand up on a flake. Climb up left (5.7 move) past a bolt. Continue up left to another bolt and then climb directly up the face above to a tricky finish.  Belay from bolts on a shelf left of the prominent, quarried slice.
location: This is the route that finishes just to the left of the 2 big cuts on the Whale.  Start just right of the big ponderosa pine.  Rappel with double ropes or a 200 foot (60 meter) rope which reaches some foothold (with rope stretch) a few feet off the ground.
protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  Bring #2 Camalot also for protection in the first corner.

4.fa: Stewart Green, Martha Morris and Brian Shelton
description: From the RRCOS guidebook: An excellent lead on perfect stone. Begin off the left side of the narrow ledge system above the Never Ever Slab.
Eds. be careful on the ledge approaching the climb.  A trip could send you plummeting a long way.
location: From the guidebook: On the far left or south side of the Whale. It's easiest to access them by the path that climbs the left side of the lower slab, then back across the slab top to the cliff base.
protection: 5 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor. Same anchor as
Dreamtime
, which is to the left.

description: This the 3rd route from the left on Sayers' Wall. It has the obvious start in the middle of the wall. It involves smearing with good protection. It seems hardest at the start. Move up and left until a solid finish up to the anchor. This is a solid climb and is worth doing.
protection: Very well bolted - 5 bolts to a solid 2 bolt anchor.

description: There is a little bit of awkward stemming/offwidth climbing to first piece of protection. Step right of a bush onto a face/arete, and find protection through intermittent cracks. Climb up to the obvious, right-facing corner, and from here, either brave the steep slab to
Katrina's
anchors or climb the corner till it flattens out step left, and downclimb to the anchors.
location: This ascends an obvious water streak to the right of
Katrina
protection: Small pro - cams 0.3-0.75 and a set of nuts.

description: This route is really fun. Smeary feet with good hands.
location: This is the last route on the wall.
protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.

description: Climb the easiest corner/seam directly under the anchor. Continue past the left of the bulge to stay true to the grade.
location: Access the anchors by topping out via
Shred Bread
and walking climber's left.
protection: This is a toprope only at the moment. It has a 2 bolt anchor with Metolius rap hangers.

description: This is a long and fun route up the right side of the Ripple Wall.  The crux may be getting off the ground.  Although mostly easy climbing, it is a bit runout by Red Rock standards, but not bad at all.  I recommend belaying your partner up to the anchor to avoid rope drag and to enjoy the view.
Rappel with two ropes
to the
left
to make the pull easier
location: This is the third route from the right on the Ripple Wall.  Start just left of
Jumping the Gun

, angling up and left past two drilled angle pitons.  Continue traversing straight left to a third piton, then climb straight up to the very top of the wall.  The last piton currently has a screw link on it, but this is not the anchor, continue another 25 feet or so to reach the obvious anchor.  Rappel with TWO ropes.
protection: 5 drilled pitons, 2 huge eyebolts, and 1 railroad spike!  Make sure you have 3 long runners to girth-hitch the eyebolts and spike.  Anchor consists of 3 drilled angle pitons and two modern bolts.

description: This is a route that is toproped from
The Mad Scientist's
anchors. Instead of following the bolts for
TMS

, go straight at the anchors directly from below them. Start in the gully that is easy climbing. Face the more vertical wall with the right-facing ledge above, and this requires a bit of smearing. The crux is the same as
TMS
but is left of the bolts and can be more challenging if you stay away from the flake to the left. Then, it's easy sailing to the TR from above the flake.
location: Start about 10 feet left of
The Mad Scientist's
beginning.
protection: 2 anchors at the top - TR from the same anchors as
The Mad Scientist

description: This is a really nice climb. Approach as for
The West Face
. Scramble up a gully to the start of the climb. Climb 2 pitches up the slab beside the obvious, left-facing corner system on the right side of the west face. The first pitch has a funky start.

Pitch 1 - there is a hard move, boulder problem really, that goes over a bulge and gets you up to a stance where the first bolt is. It would seem that either side of the bulge will go, but most people tend to favor the left side. Climb the rest of the pitch to the anchors.

Pitch 2 - edge past eight bolts up a superb slab to a notch on the left just below the top of the cliff. Notice the missing anchors on your right. You can go back along the ledge for 10 to 15' to a tree and belay. This tree can be rappelled from to get back down the west face. You can use 2 ropes or 1 rope with a little down scrambling. Or, continue over the top and belay from a tree about 30' back.
Use the standard Pinnacle descent if you go over the top.
protection: P1: 5 bolts to a two bolt anchor plus stoppers and camming units up to mid-size.
P2: 10 bolts to a slung tree for an anchor for either the left exit (5.7), or straight up exit (5.9) and possibly one small to medium piece above the belay.
Per
Reggie Slavens
: as a result of a recent serious accident, a bolt has been added to the 'left of the bulge' start option.

4.fa: Ian Green? Ed Schmitt and Mark Van Horn?
description: Start up the crack and over the bulge. End at the anchors at the top on the right hand side above the loose rocks wedged in the crack. The first couple hangers twist a bit making the sharp end seem a bit more intense, but hey... what's climbing without the risk?
Also, this is a great warm up problem. You can set up a top rope for "Common Misconception" from the anchors, walk off, or rap down.
location: 3rd problem from the right. Look for the crack.
protection: A few draws, or walk up to it from the top of the cliff and top rope it.

4.fa: U.S. Army climbers, 1950s, FFA: Harvey Carter, 1950
description: Super classic. This is one of the best 5.7 climbs in Colorado aNd ascends the narrow North ridge of Montezuma's Tower, offering up good moves on reasonably solid conglomerate sandstone, tremendous exposure and short cruxes. Usually it is done in two pitches, although it is possible to do it in one pitch with a 60m rope. Keep in mind that you still will need two ropes for the rap off.

Begin at the base of the North ridge, climbing unprotected but moderate rock to the first of three giant eyebolts (5.7). Run it out up the ridge (5.4), threading a pothole along the way if you feel uncomfortable, until reaching a small ledge which, in 1999, had a 3-pin belay. One of the pins could be pulled out by hand but due to its orientation, provided good protection.
Pitch two is a short one, moving past a short vertical section (5.7) to the summit and a 3-pin belay.
Rap off to the West with two ropes (or one 70m rope)
protection: A few QDs, a very small selection of cams and stoppers, and a long sling to thread a pothole.

description: This is located on the southwest face of North Gateway Rock, known as the Finger Face for the namesake and easily identifiable "Finger", just right of the Tourist Gully.

Finger Ramp ascends the left-leaning ramp past several good bolts to a three bolt chain belay in the Finger alcove.  The crux, exciting for both the leader and second, is the traverse on the outside of the Finger between the last bolt and the belay.  A pink tricam in a pocket will provide psychological protection before the first bolt.
protection: 5 QDs and a pink tricam (or orange Alien).
Eds. Originally, there were 3 pins on the route.  Now, additional bolt(s) were placed by a group of local climbers working in conjunction with the Park & Rec department to improve the safety.

4.fa: [FA: Harvey Carter and Cleve McCarty FFA: Mark Rolofson And Jeff Britt]
description: To correct previous wrongs (see description of
Fastest Drill
), I've decided to enter a separate description for Unzipped.
Unzipped is the left-most route on the
Cowboy Boot Crack
Face.  It is three bolts to a two bolt anchor.  The "s" rating is given due to the long, unprotected opening traverse.  You can TR the mostly unprotected
Warren-Johnson
route to the left from these anchors.  A 60m rope will reach the main platform, but as always tie knots in the end of the rope to be sure.

From the main platform, traverse left to the farthest line of bolts.  It is not hard climbing, but mentally it can get to you a bit. Head up the obvious bolt line, staying more or less to the left of the line.  Step up the commiting move above bolt #2 and grab edges and a final hueco before the anchors.
protection: 3 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.

description: From the scooped ledge above Amazing Grace, the route climbs out left, around the corner onto a large slab that forms the upper and southern section of the West Face of North Gateway Rock.

P1)  Step up and left around the corner, being careful of loose rock and clip a decent fixed pin.  Above this you can place a high #0.75 Camalot, but then step back down and left for an airy 5.7 traverse move to a good ledge with another piton.  From here, continue traversing up and left along a crack/seam feature with some bushes in it.  You can place a #0.4 Camalot and higher up a #1 Camalot  along this crack (you may even want to sling a bush, although it probably wouldn't hold).  Continue above the bushes just left of the crack up perfect potholes to the anchor which consists of 1 drilled piton and an old Leeper-Z piton that sticks half way out.  (5.7 R, 130 feet)

P2)  Climb above the anchor to the top of a pillar and clip an OK piton.  Continue up on easy but loose terrain past 2 worthless pitons, to a fourth piton which seems a little more solid, but still seems questionable.  From here, you can traverse right to the ridge crest, where you can place a yellow C3 Camalot (1/2").  Then climb the ridge, with another good placement for the #0.4 Camalot to a new 2-bolt anchor at the top of the wall.  You can also climb straight up past the last piton, but a fall here could be tragic.  (5.6 R/X, 130 feet)

The X rating in the description is due to the long runouts on the second pitch, with quite worthless protection.  The climbing is easy but very loose and requires a cool head.  If you fall off this pitch, it's possible that you could rip all the protection (although I hope the first piton would hold).  Falling directly onto the anchor in this scenario could possibly generate enough force to rip the anchor (although I personally think it would hold, but the Leeper-Z makes me wonder).  Similarly, don't fall prior to clipping the first piton on the first pitch.  The first pitch is also scary and runout, but doesn't feel quite as sketchy, and at least the anchor at the start of the climb seems bomber.  Either way, long whippers  are a distinct possibility on this climb, and will make you wonder if your protection would hold.  But for those that are ready and willing to take on this type of Garden adventure, the climbing and the position is amazing.
location: This route begins from the large scooped out ledge in the West Face of North Gateway Rock, which is formed by the Tweedle Dum Spire on the south and the main formation of North Gateway Rock to the north.  The scoop is also at the top of Amazing Grace (the hard face climb just left of
The Warren Route

Approach by scrambling up the Tourist Gully almost to its top.  Look for the easiest access to gain the ridge of the rock that is to the west (climber's left).  There is an obvious notch to look for which is higher than the notch formed by the base of the the Tweedle Dum Spire.  Once you've accessed the ridge you have two options.  The original route down-climbs the ridge at 5.4 with limited pro to the saddle below the Tweedle Dum Spire.  From here, you can rappel 60' or so to the large scooped ledge above Amazing Grace (chain anchors - from here you can rappel 150' to the ground).  Alternatively, you may avoid down-climbing the ridge by carefully accessing a 2-pin anchor just below the notch.  This is an exposed maneuver, but leaves a direct 100' rappel down to a two-pin anchor above and to the left of the chain anchors for Amazing Grace.  This is the start of the climb.  (You can also approach by climbing Amazing Grace or the first pitch of Falling From Grace).

This route is somewhat tricky in trying to put it in a rational subarea for North Gateway Rock.  It lies on the West face, but the easiest approach is from the Tourist Gully.  Still, it can be approached via
The Zipper
The Warren Route
, and Amazing Grace.  So, it's a challenge for the hierarchical organization on this website.
protection: P1) 2 or 3 pins, #0.4 - #1 Camalots.  2 pin anchor.
P2) 4 pins, yellow C3 Camalot, #0.4 Camalot.  2 new bolts anchor.

Tag the summit, then descend by walking north on a large ledge on the West face, then going back through a notch to the east, with a short down-climb to gain a large ledge on the East face.  Walk back south to access the top of the Tourist Gully and down-climb from there.

description: This climbs the obvious line of large pockets on the Red Twin Spire.  It stays in the shade most of the time, so it is a good summer route.  Back up the fixed pins as they are not very good.
protection: [2 bolts and 3 drilled pitons]. Back them up with stoppers and some medium cams or it is very frightening.
Addendum: please consider rappeling instead of lowering, when you clean the route, to reduce wear on the top anchor chains. Thanks!

4.fa: FA: Paul Radigen, 1950s  FFA: Harvey Carter, 1950s
description: This has a tricky start and is a little frightening. It can be toproped after leading the
South Ridge
.  Climb up the steep north ridge on big holds.
protection: Fixed pins, stoppers, small to medium cams.

description: This has sandy chimney climbing up the super obvious northern chimney.
Start with unprotected, moderate climbing up the start of
Triple Exposure
for 40 feet until
Triple Exposure
cuts right and this route goes left. Follow loose climbing past some drilled angles and a piece of rebar into the chimney. The second pitch follows a sandy chimney with potholes to a sling.
Rap
Triple Exposure
location: Ascend the obvious (from the main parking lot) chimney on the north side of North Gateway. Follow directions to the start of
Triple Exposure
protection: There is no fixed gear. Bring a standard rack up to #4 Camalot.

description: This route is located on the east face of Kindergarten Rock. Park at the Kindergarten Rock parking area and walk up the road.  You will see a faint trail on the left side of the road cutting through a field of POISON IVY.  Scramble up the steep hill to the base of the prominent crack in the middle of the formation.
You can climb this in two or three pitches.  I prefer two.
